WRITING.TEXT: I think that most moviegoers who watch these movies probably don't. It's just pretty fascinating for movie geeks like myself to see the franchise evolve from four movies in a row that always ended up Rotten on Rotten Tomatoes to its next three movies becoming critical darlings (with each one being rated Fresh). Fate of the Furious looks to continue that tend since it's now at 73% fresh as of this writing.
I'm really happy to see it fresh now. I imagine that the final Rotten Tomatoes core will be within the range of 69% and 79%, which is what the last three films fell between.
The Rotten Tomatoes score has risen to 67% now. Hooray! :)

WRITING.TEXT: Unless both studios work together and make it a co-production, which isn't impossible, I guess (see the deal that Marvel Studios made with Sony regarding Spider-Man: Homecoming, which is distributing the film). Two of the biggest franchises around in one film? That film would make ALL THE MONEY.

Considering the next 3 films are very likely to gross over $1 billion worldwide each (Furious 7 grosses $1.5 billion worldwide), it would be a dumb financial move for Universal not to continue the franchise after the tenth installment (which is the third part of a trilogy starting with Fast 8). So I think we'll be seeing those movies for a very long time.
Golfer-In-Chief

I'm not surprised to see Smurfs: The Lost Village disappointing. There was clearly no demand for a third film. Still, it probably will be somewhat profitable in the end.
I am surprised to see Going in Style do pretty well. Zach Braff (the director), you finally have a hit!
Glad to see Kong: Skull Island and Get Out continue to hold well.
Yeah, that kind of sucks. At this point, Power Rangers is going to have to perform exceptionally well in Japan and China to justify greenlighting a sequel at this point.
Wild theory: The Fast and the Furious films are actually incredibly elaborate prequels to the Riddick films. Both are distributed by Universal, too. SYNERGY!

WRITING.TEXT:
Unfortunately, Power Rangers had a huge 64% drop from last weekend. So it's looking very unlikely it will cross $100 million domestically, unless it has miraculously low drops from this point forward. Scott Mendelson at Forbes believes it will end up with a $95 million final gross in the U.S.
Also, its overseas gross so far has been very meh. It's going to have to do extremely well in Japan and China, in my opinion, to justify a sequel. I hope it does, though - another film in the franchise would be dope.

Top 10 films of the weekend per Deadline:
1.) The Boss Baby (20th Century Fox/DWA), 3,773 theaters / $15.6M Fri. (includes $1.5M in previews) / $20.2M Sat. (+28%) / $14.15M Sun. (-30%) / 3-day cume: $50M+ / Wk 1
2.) Beauty and the Beast (DIS), 4,210 theaters / $13.1M Fri. (-34%) / $19.6M Sat. (+51%) / $14.7M Sun. (25%) / 3-day cume: $47.5M (-47%) / Total cume: $395.4M / Wk 3
3.) Ghost in the Shell (PAR/DWA/REL), 3,440 theaters / $7.6M Fri. (includes $1.8M) / $6.67M Sat. (-13%) / $4.3M Sun. (-35%) / 3-day cume: $18.6M /Wk 1
4.) Sabans Power Rangers (LGF), 3,693 theaters (0) / $4M Fri. (-73%) / $6.1M Sat. (+53%) / $4.3M Sun. (-30%) / 3-day cume: $14.4M (-64%) / Total cume: $65M / Wk 2
5.) Kong: Skull Island (20th/Legendary), 3,141 theaters (-525) / $2.3M Fri. (-37%) / $3.78M Sat. (+59%) / $2.6M Sun. (-40%) / 3-day cume: $9.1M / Total cume: $147.78M / Wk 4
6.) Logan (Fox), 2,323 theaters (-840)/ $1.71M Fri. (-34%) / $2.5M Sat. (+55%) / $1.8M Sun. (-30%) / 3-day cume: $6.2M / Total cume: $211.8M / Wk 5
7.) Get Out (UNI), 1,844 theaters (-630) / $1.73M Fri. (-31%) / $2.48M Sat. (+44%) / $1.6M Sun. (35%) / 3-day cume: $5.8M / Total cume: $156.8M / Wk 6
8.) Life (Skydance/Sony), 3,146 theaters (0) / $1.65M Fri. (-63%) / $2.3M Sat. (+45%) / $1.5M Sun. (-35%) / 3-day cume: $5.5M (-55%) / Total: $22.3M / Wk 2
9.) CHIPS (WB), 2,464 theaters (0) / $1.1M Fri. (-55%) / $1.68M Sat. (+43%) / $1.77M Sun. (-30%) / 3-day: $4M (-48%) / Total: $14.3M / Wk 2
10.) Zookeepers Wife (FOC), 541 theaters / $998K Fri. / $1.3M Sat. (+31%) / $800K Sun. (-40%) / 3-day: $3.2M / Wk 1
http://deadline.com/2017/04/ghost-in-the-shell-scarlett-johansson-boss-baby-beauty-and-the-beast-weekend-box-office-1202056616/

WRITING.TITLE: Ghost in the Shell bombs with $19 million, an expensive flop for Paramount. The Boss Baby gets the #1 spot with a better-than-expected $49 million, edging out Beauty and the Beast at #2 (grossing $47.5 million, raising its stunning total to $395.4 million and $876.3 million worldwide).
Stephen King Compares Donald Trump to Two of His Most Unsavory Characters
Box Office: 'Boss Baby' Demands Attention With Bossy $49M, No. 1 Opening
Federal Judge Says Trump Incited Violence at Campaign Rally, Lawsuit Against Him and Supporters Can Proceed

WRITING.TEXT: In the shape of a L on her forehead

Wow, Ghost in the Shell is quite a bomb. The future looks dicey indeed for future live-action anime adaptations.
Great number for The Boss Baby - I definitely was not expecting it to end up beating Beauty and the Beast (which nonetheless did very well) this weekend.
It sucks to see Power Rangers have a huge drop - I'm really hoping it does well in China and Japan, so it might get a sequel. Scott Mendelson is predicting a $95 million domestic gross for it, but it will likely fall short of $100 million at this point.
Kong: Skull Island looks to end at its domestic run at about $160-170 million or so, and it's been doing great overseas. Looks to be a big success for Warner Brothers - it's nice to see iy outperform expectations, since many expected it to fail.
Get Out continues to have great legs.
